0.text:
Today I'm coming here to talk to you
about how i became fluent in English.

4.text:
It's a question I get asked a lot of
times, and also to share some tips from

8.text:
my personal experience on speaking a
foreign language or second language,

13.text:
on how to communicate well and be
understood in a foreign language when

18.text:
you're living abroad. If you don't
know anything about me, and this is the first

21.text: video of mine that you're watching,

23.text:
I am originally from Brazil, I was born
and raised there and I lived in Brazil

27.text:
for 23 years. Then I moved to the UK
and I've been living here for the last

34.text:
Nowadays, I can say that I sometimes, well
most of the time, I feel more confident

39.text:
speaking in English than I do in
Portuguese, and I think that's quite an

43.text:
achievement for someone who wasn't
brought up in an english-speaking

46.text:
country and learned english as a second
language. So I thought this video may be

51.text:
interesting or useful to anyone out
there who's learning English now and who

56.text:
is struggling to become fluent or to
know what to do to better their English.

61.text:
My english is far from being perfect and
I make mistakes all the time, but

66.text:
I consider myself capable enough of
holding a conversation, and I do all

71.text:
my YouTube videos in English, which is
good practice as well. So I'll just get

75.text:
started with how I started to learn
English. When you go to school in Brazil

79.text: and you get to a certain age,

81.text:
English becomes part of the curriculum
and it's one of the mandatory languages

84.text:
to learn, and so I started learning in
school. But the curriculum in school is

90.text:
very limited and you really don't learn
an awful amount of English in school.

94.text: So if you want to be able to speak English properly,

97.text:
as a general rule, you have to enroll in
a private English school. And that's what

102.text:
most people do in Brazil and most of my
friends did and when I was growing up.

107.text: I was about 13 when I started studying English, or 14. Around about that age, 13 to 14.

114.text:
And I was going twice a week to a
private English school.

118.text:
It wasn't something that was forced by
my parents. My mum always liked English.

123.text:
She did do private English lessons when
she was much younger, so it was something

127.text:
that she was keen for us all to know and
to learn from a young age.

131.text:
And we were just generally
interested in the English world,

135.text:
in the English-speaking world and the
culture. American culture, British culture,

139.text:
which were the two biggest cultures that
we were exposed to in Brazil, growing up.

144.text:
We had lessons, and we started with Basic,
Beginners and stuff, and carried on

149.text:
progressing to Intermediate, then Advanced
and then we got our degrees.

154.text:
What happened to me was that, I very
quickly realised I had a passion

157.text:
for languages, and that I actually really
enjoyed learning English. And so,

162.text:
very quickly I progressed and developed my
English because I was practicing so much

168.text:
and enjoying it so much. I wasn't just
learning in the English school,

172.text:
I was going home, and I was watching things in
English, and I was listening to music

177.text:
in English and trying to understand the
lyrics and translate it. And that kind of

182.text:
helped a lot with my fluency and it
helped just to solidify the concepts that

187.text:
I'd learned from the books in my
English school, and I'd come home

192.text:
and it wasn't something that I was forced to do,
it was something that I wanted to do.

196.text:
So I would watch things in English and try to
understand what they were saying.

199.text:
I loved my dictionary, I walked around everywhere 
with my Portuguese to English Dictionary

204.text:
translating words that I'd come across
and that I didn't know.

208.text:
So, then when I was 14 to 15,
my sister and I went abroad.

213.text:
We went to Disneyland, and that was our first
experience in an English-speaking country.

218.text:
And I just thought it was amazing
that I was able to understand certain things.

223.text: I wasn't fluent at all at that point.

225.text:
I just had a very basic knowledge 
of English, but I just got so

229.text:
intrigued and interested in all of it.
A year later, I made my first trip to London.

236.text:
I came to stay with a friend. 
I was 15 at the time.

239.text:
Yeah, I think so, 15 going on 16, 
and I absolutely loved it.

244.text:
I fell in love with the British culture then 
and I just did not want to do

249.text:
anything else, 
I just wanted to learn English.

251.text:
I was staying with a group of friends
who only spoke English, which kind of

256.text:
forced me to speak English as well and
to kind of get out of my comfort zone,

260.text: which was the best thing for me.

262.text:
So after I came back from abroad I did
the placement test to see where my level

267.text:
of English was after having spent that
time abroad, because that does boost up

271.text:
your English level quite a lot, and I had
jumped quite a lot of levels.

276.text:
So I went from being the start of
Intermediate, to going straight to Advanced

281.text:
and I skipped the whole of the
Intermediate course because I had

284.text:
already built up so much for vocabulary
and learned so much just by being abroad.

289.text: So that really really helped me.

291.text:
I finished the Advanced level and I didn't
stop there. I carried on studying because

296.text:
I didn't want to lose my fluency and if
any of you out there are learning

299.text:
English abroad, you know how easy it is to
quickly lose your fluency

304.text:
if you've been abroad, if you studied
abroad or did an interchange programme.

307.text:
And then suddenly you're back home and
no one speaks English on a daily basis.

312.text:
It's really hard to keep up with the
language if you're not constantly talking.

318.text:
So I enrolled - my English school
at the time offered what they called

322.text:
a conversation course, which was basically,
you finish the class, you finish the course.

328.text:
There's no more grammar or anything to learn, 
you've learned everything that we offer.

332.text:
But now we offer you the chance 
to keep coming back

334.text:
twice a week with a group of people who
are still interested in keeping that

339.text:
English alive and we will just have
conversations, basically. There will be

342.text:
topics to be discussed every week, we'll
have hand-outs and things,

348.text:
and I'm sure you still be learning. 
So I did that and that was brilliant.

351.text:
I loved that and I recommend that anyone 
who has finished their whole English course

356.text: and is wondering what to do.

357.text:
Go and find a conversation course. 
You might think that you're putting money

360.text:
down the drain, but you're not, because
you're keeping that whole investment

365.text:
that you made 
in your English course, alive.

368.text: You're basically saving your fluency in English,

371.text:
because you're practicing twice a week at least 
and you get to speak English that you wouldn't

376.text:
get to speak otherwise.  And you also have 
a teacher there to answer any questions.

381.text: That was basically what happened to me.

383.text:
It's not groundbreaking, I didn't do
anything different to what anyone does

387.text:
but I think I just already had a
predisposition to languages, and the fact

392.text:
that I went abroad really helped build
up my confidence in speaking English.

398.text:
So for starters I had a very very strong
American accent because my teachers

402.text:
in Brazil, they all had American accents and
then when I came to the UK, I fell in love

408.text:
with the British accent and somehow
my brain was able to completely change

412.text:
my accent from being American to British.
And my husband being British,

417.text:
at the time when we were going out, 
we were still boyfriend and girlfriend.

421.text:
He is Welsh, and my brain just sucked in 
his Welsh accent, and now I have

428.text:
kind of like a Welsh accent, mixed in with a
Brazilian accent and whatever accents

432.text:
I've have absorbed throughout the years. 
But mostly Welsh, I think.

436.text:
I pick up accents very quickly, 
even in Portuguese.

440.text:
It's quite funny, actually. Because if I'm
talking to someone - a Brazilian person

444.text:
with a different accent to mine, 
my accent morphs into their accent.

449.text:
I really have no control over it - it just happens. 
So that happened in English as well.

454.text: The more I spent time with British people,

457.text:
the more my accent got better,
and I just kept on speaking.

464.text:
Now that that part is over, let's get on
to my top tips for speaking English

471.text:
and making yourself understood in a
foreign language when you're living abroad.

475.text:
My first tip, and I think this is the
most important tip when you're

480.text:
struggling to make yourself understood
in a foreign language is: make it easy

485.text:
for people to understand you. 
Pronounce your words, open your mouth

489.text:
and say the words. Don't mumble, 
don't speak quietly,

491.text:
because people will find it difficult to understand you,
especially with the accent and all.

496.text:
If you're talking about: 'Do you want a cup of tea?' 
It might seem silly,

500.text:
but that can save a lot frustration
 when you're trying to

504.text:
communicate and people can't understand
what you're saying.

507.text:
Gesticulate with your hands, use your mouth, 
use your facial expressions.

513.text:
try to pronounce things from your native
language in a way that people can understand.

518.text:
For example, Brazilian football players
are very very popular abroad.

521.text:
And that's a topic of conversation whenever
people find that I'm from Brazil.

525.text:
And one football player that you may know 
very well is, Ronaldo.

532.text:
I wouldn't say 'Ronaldo' if I was
talking to a Brazilian person.

536.text:
I would say 'Ronaldo', 
because that's how we say it in Portuguese.

540.text:
But, if I say that to someone who speaks English only, 
or who only heard his name in the English media

547.text:
being referred to as 'Ronaldo', that's
going to cause a little bit of miscommunication.

552.text:
So instead of making that conversation easier, 
you're making it harder, if you know what I mean,

556.text:
by pronouncing it the way that
you would in Portuguese.

560.text:
So if you know how people 
in English-speaking countries

564.text:
speak certain words from your native language, 
then make it easier for them. Why not?

569.text:
It doesn't really matter, you're not making a mistake. 
The important thing is that

573.text:
you know that you know 
the way it's supposed to be said,

577.text:
but in that particular context, it's much easier 
for you to make it easier for yourself

582.text: and for the person that you're speaking to.

583.text:
My second tip is: don't obsess 
over your mistakes.

588.text:
They really don't matter that much, 
and if you told me that

591.text: when I was learning English as a teenager,

594.text:
I wouldn't have followed your advice, 
but I hope some of you will.

599.text:
As a teenager I worried far too much
about my mistakes and about

603.text:
what other people thought of what I was saying wrong, 
and that prevented me from

608.text:
starting conversations because I didn't
want to make mistakes, especially in English.

613.text: The first time I came to the UK

615.text:
I would not start a conversation, 
I would wait until someone would start

618.text:
a conversation with me, because I was too
worried of saying things the wrong way.

622.text:
But soon enough I realised 
by talking to people

626.text:
how little they care about your mistakes.
If you're trying your best,

630.text:
and you're speaking most of it correctly, or
if you're getting the general gist

636.text:
people really don't care that much. 
Even native speakers of English make mistakes.

641.text:
And that's something that you'll learn.
That your grammar will be much better than

647.text:
a lot of native speakers. Obviously there
are a lot of people in English-speaking

650.text:
countries that have amazing grammar and
things like that, but you'll be surprised

654.text:
how good your Grammar and your knowledge
of the English language is, coming from

659.text:
learning English as a foreign language.
So don't obsess over your mistakes.

664.text:
If you feel like you've made a mistake,
don't stop a conversation to correct yourself.

668.text:
Just carry on speaking and
keep the conversation flowing,

673.text: and that will make you more confident.

675.text:
You know in your mind 
that you made a mistake,

676.text:
but you'll correct it next time.
Don't worry that person is not gonna judge you

680.text:
on that mistake, it's just going to make 
life a little bit easier if you're trying to

686.text:
Tip number three is: practice, practice, practice.
Whenever you can, wherever you can.

693.text:
If you have a friend abroad 
that you talk to online,

696.text:
talk to them on skype, talk to them on Facetime,
but actually talk to them.

701.text:
Writing is good, but you will only get your fluency
by practicing your speaking.

707.text:
And if you've learned English as a second
language, you know the very important

710.text:
parts of English, such as writing, reading
listening and speaking.

716.text:
I think the hardest one for people to
achieve fluency in.

if you know anyone in town that speaks
English as a first language, go and speak to them

725.text: and just practice as much as you can.

727.text: But if you can't do that,

729.text:
practice on your own, even in your house.
I used to do that all the time in my bedroom.

and you can call me crazy, but that
